The maximum loss and maximum gain for the combination of contracts can be calculated as follows:

The maximum loss, which can occur at expiration date, is the difference between the lower strike price minus the higher strike price for each option minus the net credit received. So, the maximum loss is: $85 - $83 - $2.42 x 100 - $2.18 x 100 - $2.88 x 100 = $1.50.

The maximum gain, which can occur when the stock price moves beyond the strike
prices, is the difference between the higher strike price plus the net credit received and the lower strike price for each option. So, the maximum gain is: $85 + $2.42 x 100 - $80 - $2.88 x 100 = $25.58.

Please note that this is only an estimation based on the information given and the actual outcome will depend on the stock price on the expiration date.

Maximum loss: [-$1.50] (difference between strikes and net credit received)

Maximum gain: [$25.58] (difference between higher strike and net credit received minus lower strike minus net debit paid)

Remember that these figures are for a 100-share contract and the actual payout and losses will be related to that amount. Note: The breakeven stock price is the price at which the net premium received for selling the call and put options is equal to the net debit paid for buying the call and put options. This means that if the stock price equals the breakeven price, the trade will be at neutral position and the trader will not make or lose any money from the trade.
